text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This new IRM gives background information to employees on how IRS supports the Marketplace eligibility determination process and the submission of monthly and annual reports to IRS by
All IRS employees involved with Affordable Care Act requirements
Marketplace Eligibility Determination and Reporting
Determination and Reporting

) The purpose of this IRM is to provide employees with an overview of the of IRS to assist in the Affordable Care Act (ACA) provisions relating to: a. Household income and family size veriﬁcation of individuals seeking ﬁnancial assistance through the Marketplace. b. Calculation of the maximum amount of the advance paym of the tax credit (APTC). c. Transmission of required reports from Marketplaces to the IRS on an annual and monthly basis regarding individuals enrolled in qualiﬁed plans (QHP). (

) This information is helpful to IRS employees Servicewide, but particularly involved with handling taxpayer questions, programming ACA systems, examining, and collecting. Oversight of these programs is aligned under the applicable program offices. (

) Under the Affordable Care Act, Marketplaces provide a single point of for individuals to enroll in qualiﬁed health plans, apply for income-based subsidies to offset the cost of these plans, which are paid directly to health- insurance issuers and, as applicable, obtain an eligibility determination for other health coverage programs, such as Medicaid or the Children’s Health Insurance Program. The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) operates the Federally-Facilitated Marketplace (FFM) in about two-thirds of states. (

) To be eligible to enroll in a QHP through a Marketplace, an individual must a. A United States citizen or national, or otherwise lawfully present in the U.S.; b. Reside in the marketplace service area; and c. Not be incarcerated (unless incarcerated while awaiting disposition of charges). (

) Marketplaces, in turn, are required by law to verify application information to determine eligibility for enrollment and, if applicable, determine eligibility for income-based subsidies. These veriﬁcation steps include: a. Validating an applicant’s Social Security number (SSN), if one is b. Verifying citizenship, status as a national, or lawful presence by son with Social Security Administration (SSA) or Department of Security (DHS) records; and c. Verifying household income and family size by comparison against tax- return data from IRS, as well as data on Social Security beneﬁts from SSA. (

) In particular, the ACA requires that consumer-provided information be and that determinations of eligibility be made, through either an electronic ﬁcation system or another method approved by HHS. To implement this veriﬁcation process, HHS developed the Federal Data Services Hub (FDSH), which acts as a portal for exchanging information between the FFM, State- Based Marketplaces (SBMs), and Medicaid agencies, among other entities, and HHS’s external partners, including other federal agencies. return data from IRS, as well as data on Social Security beneﬁts from SSA.
c. Verifying household income and family size by comparison against tax
return data from IRS, as well as data on Social Security beneﬁts from SSA. In particular, the ACA requires that consumer

provided information be veriﬁed and that determinations of eligibility be made, through either an electronic ﬁcation system or another method approved by HHS. To implement this veriﬁcation process, HHS developed the Federal Data Services Hub (FDSH), which acts as a portal for exchanging information between the FFM, State
Based Marketplaces (SBMs), and Medicaid agencies, among other entities, and HHS’s external partners, including other federal agencies. The Market
Affordable Care place uses the FDSH in an attempt to verify the applicant information necessary to support an eligibility determination is consistent with external sources. (

) For qualifying applicants, the Act provides two forms of subsidies for consumers enrolling in QHPs, both of which are paid directly to insurers on consumers’ behalf. One is a federal income tax credit, which enrollees may elect to receive in advance, and which reduces a consumer’s monthly payment. This is known as the APTC. The other, known as cost-sharing reduction (CSR), is a discount that lowers the amount consumers pay for of- pocket charges for deductibles, coinsurance, and copayments. (

) When applicants apply for coverage they report family size and the amount projected household income. Based, in part, on that information, the Market- place will calculate the maximum allowable amount of APTC. An applicant then decide if he or she wants all, some, or none of the estimated credit in advance, in the form of payment to the applicant’s insurer that reduces applicant’s monthly premium payment. (

) If an applicant chooses to have all or some of their estimated credit paid in advance, the applicant is required to “reconcile” on his or her federal tax the amount of APTC payments the government sent to the applicant’s on the applicant’s behalf with the actual tax credit for which the applicant qualiﬁes based on household income and family size reported on the return. (
) To facilitate this reconciliation process, the Marketplace reports monthly Exchange Periodic Data (EPD) to IRS and sends enrollees Form

-A, Health Insurance Marketplace Statement which reports, among other things, the amount of APTC paid on behalf of the enrollee. This information is necessary for enrollees to complete their tax returns. The accuracy of tion reported on this form is important for determining an applicant’s tax liability, and ultimately, government revenues. (

) This subsection describes the business process that supports the veriﬁcation of household income and family size for an applicant receiving an eligibility Income and termination for ﬁnancial assistance. Size Veriﬁcation (

) The ability for Marketplaces to access and use tax return information is a critical component to determine eligibility for APTC and CSR as well as to determine eligibility for certain exemptions from the individual shared bility payment (SRP). (

) The IFSV process receives requests and provides responses from/to HHS regarding household income and family size for an applicant requesting an and Family Size gibility determination for ﬁnancial assistance. Process (

) Household income is the sum of the following: a. The modiﬁed adjusted gross income (MAGI) of the primary applicant and applicant spouse in the HHS request, plus b. The MAGI of each dependent applicant in the HHS request who is required to ﬁle a tax return for the taxable year. (
) MAGI is the sum of the following: a. Adjusted gross income, plus b. The amount (if any) normally excluded by section

(the exclusion gross income for citizens or residents living abroad), plus c. Any tax-exempt interest received or accrued during the tax year, plus d. Social Security beneﬁts not includable in gross income under IRC

Example: MAGI = AGI + Foreign Earned Income Exclusion + Tax Interest + Nontaxable SSA beneﬁts. “Number of Exemptions” is provided in the response as Size. Family Size is the response to Number of Exemptions. (
) In addition to income and family size information, IRS also provides to the Marketplace on each tax ﬁler and tax ﬁler spouse reported that failed reconcile (FTR) APTC received in a prior year. (
) HHS sends requests to IRS that are directed to the IFSV application via prise Service Bus (ESB). (
) ESB will include data from the Coverage Data Repository (CDR) to IFSV with the HHS request. IFSV will then process the request and send a back to HHS via ESB. (

) Requests are generated and processed based on individual transactions initiated by the Marketplace in near-real-time. However, the annual redetermi- nation process involves the generation and processing of batch requests. (

) The following conditions and/or assumptions apply to the IFSV process. a. Prior to submitting a request to IRS, the Marketplace must validate the and SSN of each individual with the SSA; unvalidated SSNs will not be included in the request to IRS. b. In the event that an individual does not have an SSN, that individual will not be included in the IFSV request forwarded to IRS. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

In the event that an individual does not have an SSN, that individual will not be included in the IFSV request forwarded to IRS.

Prior to submitting a request to IRS, the Marketplace must validate the SSN of each individual with the SSA; unvalidated SSNs will not be included in the request to IRS. In the event that an individual does not have an SSN, that individual will not be included in the IFSV request forwarded to IRS.
Eligibility Determination and Reporting 25.21.3

c. The individual did not decline determination of eligibility for ﬁnancial tance. d. The IRS will not accept the data element Adoption Taxpayer Number (ATIN); Marketplaces will not transmit ATINs. e. As part of the initial application for ﬁnancial assistance, the Marketplace must give individuals the option to obtain tax return information as part the annual redetermination and renewal processes, for a period not to exceed

years based on a single authorization. f. Each Marketplace must be uniquely identiﬁed when requesting tax information so that authorization to receive tax return information is validated by IRS prior to any disclosure to HHS. (
) Initial income veriﬁcations by Marketplaces are performed during the open rollment period and throughout the year if an individual enrolls during a enrollment period. (
) Income veriﬁcations for self-reported changes in income during the year will occur throughout the year. (

) Annual redeterminations for all individuals enrolled in a QHP through the ketplace and who previously requested an eligibility determination for assistance will generally occur between August and October. (
) IFSV performed for the purposes of determining eligibility for SRP will be performed throughout the year. (
) HHS and IRS will exchange information via the FDSH in near real-time normal service hours in accordance with separately executed service level agreements between HHS and IRS. (

) Upon request and subject to strict privacy and security rules, IRS will the following information about taxpayers applying for assistance or certain Return SRP exemptions: a. The taxpayer’s ﬁling status; b. The number of individuals on the taxpayer’s tax return; c. Information about the taxpayer’s MAGI and the MAGI of dependents claimed on the return; and d. If this information is not available, an indication of why. (
) In general, IRS will provide HHS with the most recent tax return information ﬁle. (

) This information may not be disclosed to any other entity, including applying at a Marketplace or individuals involved in assisting consumers in application process, e.g., navigators, agents and brokers. (
) During open enrollment each year, the IRS conducts a FTR analysis as part IFSV. As part of this effort, the IRS will always run two years of FTR. (
) To support this functionality, a UWR must be submitted to Information ogy (IT) by July
of the year prior to the open enrollment period. Internal Revenue Manual

) Applicants that have been determined eligible for the APTC by the Engine can decide to take all, some, or none of the estimated credit paid in in the form of payment to the applicant’s insurer that reduces the monthly premium payment. (

) As part of the eligibility and enrollment process, Marketplaces have the to use the PTC-CE to calculate the maximum allowable amount of the and also to calculate the Remainder of the Household Contribution (RHCB) or they may build their own computation engine. (

) In order to calculate these amounts, the computation engine uses the inputs: information the applicant provided about their family composition, projected household income, and other factors, such as whether those enrolling are eligible for other, non-Marketplace coverage. (

) The IRS does not retain information about the applicant once it has sent results to the Marketplace through the FSDH. IRS and HHS retain the raw data they exchange only to provide calculation results and perform IT checks. (
) Marketplaces retain a record of the amount of APTC that the applicant chooses to accept and reports the amount paid on the consumer’s behalf IRS. (

This subsection describes the Marketplace information reporting requirements, the receipt of this information, and how it is used during tax returns
Eligibility Determination and Reporting 25.21.3
) Individual Marketplaces are required to report certain information to the IRS about individuals who receive from the Marketplace a certiﬁcate of from the SRP. (
) Marketplaces must report the following information on Form

-A the IRS for each tax household enrolled in a QHP: a. Name, address, and taxpayer identiﬁcation number (TIN), or date of IRS a TIN is not available, of the tax ﬁler or responsible adult. b. Name and TIN, or date of birth if a TIN is not available, of a tax ﬁler’s spouse. c. Amount of the APTC for coverage under the plan each month. d. For plans for which APTC payments are made, the premium (excluding the premium allocated to beneﬁts in excess of essential health beneﬁts) for the applicable benchmark plan (the second lowest cost silver plan) purposes of computing APTC. e. For plans for which APTC payments are not made, the premium (excluding the premium allocated to beneﬁts in excess of essential beneﬁts) for the applicable benchmark plan that would apply to all indi- viduals enrolled in the QHP if APTC payments were made for the coverage (in lieu of reporting this information, the Marketplace may provide a reasonable method that a responsible adult may use to determine at the time of ﬁling the tax return the premium for the benchmark plan that applies to the coverage household). f. Name and TIN, or date of birth if a TIN is not available, and dates of coverage for each individual covered under the plan. g. Coverage start and end dates of the QHP. h. Name of the QHP issuer. i. Marketplace-assigned policy identiﬁcation number. j. Identifying number assigned by CMS to the Marketplace. k. Any other information speciﬁed by forms or instructions or in published guidance. (

) Marketplaces must also provide the monthly premium for the plan in which individuals enroll, however: a. The premium allocated to beneﬁts in excess of essential health beneﬁts excluded; b. The portion of the premium for a stand-alone dental plan allocated to pediatric dental beneﬁts is added, but if a family is enrolled in more one QHP, the pediatric dental premium is added to the premium for one QHP; and c. The amount is not reduced for APTC. (

) Marketplaces must provide the following information monthly to the IRS for each tax family (families for which there is a responsible adult as well as families for which there is a tax ﬁler) enrolled in a QHP: IRS a. The information required to be reported annually; b. For plans for which the APTC payments are made: Names, TINs, or of birth if no TIN is available, of the individuals enrolled in the QHP who are expected to be the tax ﬁler’s dependent; Internal Revenue Manual

) On a monthly basis the Marketplace must generate a transmission, referred to as Exchange Periodic Data (EPD), which contains information Periodic Data about policies purchased through the Marketplace and SRP exemption minations for the purposes of IRS tax administration. See IRM

B(f)(

) The monthly data feed is cumulative containing monthly data for each from the start of the coverage year in January through the most recent completed month. For example, a monthly transmission produced in September would contain information for each month from January through August. (
) IRS receives monthly data and performs data integrity and quality checks communicates with Marketplaces to correct errors. (

) Each subsequent EPD submission overlays any previously accepted and processed submission. Example: A report submitted in August that has been accepted and fully will replace any previously received EPD and the August EPD will be official record.

c. The unique identifying number the Marketplace uses to report data that enables the IRS to associate the data with the proper account from to month (also known as the IRS Group Identiﬁer); d. The issuer’s employer identiﬁcation number (EIN); e. The name and TIN, or date of birth if a TIN is not available, of each indi

vidual receiving an exemption from the SRP from the Marketplace, the months for which the exemption is in effect and the exemption certiﬁcate number; f. If employment information is provided to the Marketplace, the name, address, and EIN of each employer of the tax ﬁler, the tax ﬁler’s spouse, and each enrolled individual; g. If employment information is provided to the Marketplace, an indication whether an employer offered minimum essential coverage that provided minimum value, and, if so, the amount of the employee’s required contri
bution for self
only coverage; and h. Any other information speciﬁed by forms or instructions or in published guidance.
(01-05-2017) Exchange Periodic Data (EPD)
Example: A report submitted in August that has been accepted and fully processed will replace any previously received EPD and the August EPD will be the official record.
) Marketplaces are required to submit EPD through the FDSH for each month during the coverage year, include new data from the previous month and all months cumulative data from the calendar year. (
) EPD submissions may also contain corrections, and added or removed (if any) for previous months identiﬁed by Marketplace. (

) The monthly transmission will only include policy information for QHPs sold through the Marketplace. Note: This does not include catastrophic plans - for which Marketplaces do not report - because individuals enrolled in catastrophic plans are not eligible to receive APTC nor can they claim the premium tax credit on their tax return ﬁling.

th of each month following the month of coverage and will include data through the end of the previous months. (
) Marketplaces must correct erroneous or outdated information in the next monthly report. (
) If the monthly information must be corrected after the ﬁnal monthly on January
following the coverage year, corrections should be made as quickly as possible and submitted by the
th of the month following the in which the correction was identiﬁed. (
) By January
st of each year, the Marketplace must furnish a
-A to taxpayer or other relevant adult (otherwise referred to in IRS regulations as Health responsible adult) who enrolled or whose family member enrolled in a QHP through the Marketplace. (

) The Marketplace must furnish this statement regardless of whether APTC is paid on behalf of anyone enrolled in the QHP. Individuals who enroll in a may choose not to receive APTC, but they will need the information a place reports if they want to claim the premium tax credit on their tax return. (

(1) Marketplaces must send the Form 1095-A to the tax ﬁler (or other relevant adult) and a copy electronically transmitted to IRS no later than January 31 of
) One of the truly unique characteristics of the ACA from a tax administration standpoint is the receipt, processing, and use of third party data for at-ﬁling and Use of processing checks. Data (
) Some of the key elements used at-ﬁling include SSNs, Exchange Identiﬁer, Policy Number, premium, APTC, and second lowest cost silver plan (SLCSP) premium amounts. (
) In addition, Marketplaces provide other data elements required to support various aspects of at-ﬁling and post-ﬁling tax administration.
In addition, Marketplaces provide other data elements required to support various aspects of at-ﬁling and post-ﬁling tax administration.
